https://www.thetimes.com/uk/crime/articl.title: Extinction Rebellion are criminals, says Priti Patel
https://www.thetimes.com/uk/crime/articl.text:
Activists in Extinction Rebellion are criminals who threaten the British way of life, Priti Patel said on Tuesday after the group’s blockade of printing presses.
In the harshest language used yet by any member of the government, the home secretary described the group as “so-called eco-crusaders turned criminals” who “disrupt our free society” with “guerrilla tactics”.
Speaking at the annual conference of the Police Superintendents’ Association, she vowed to crack down on the group, warning: “I refuse point-blank to allow that kind of anarchy on our streets.”
Ms Patel, whose parents set up a string of newsagents, challenged the police to use all the powers at their disposal “against those who threaten our freedoms”, describing the group as carrying out “a shameful attack on our
image: The home secretary described Extinction Rebellion protests as an “attack on our way of life”
author: Fariha Karim

https://www.thetimes.com/uk/law/article/.title: Jail has no vegan meals, complains eco-activist Roger Hallam
https://www.thetimes.com/uk/law/article/.text:
The co-founder of Extinction Rebellion complained about living in a cockroach-infested cell with inadequate vegan food as he was released on bail to face trial for allegedly plotting to vandalise trades union properties.
Roger Hallam, 54, was arrested last month and remanded in custody amid claims a Green Party member “infiltrated” a meeting and passed details to police of an alleged plot to throw paint over the buildings of four unions.
Mr Hallam, a former organic farmer and sociologist who helped set up the pressure group in 2018, was arrested alongside four others who have all worked with Extinction Rebellion.
Mr Hallam appeared yesterday via videolink at Wood Green crown court where he denied a charge of conspiracy to commit criminal damage.
Last year he
image: Roger Hallam helped set up Extinction Rebellion two years ago but has now left the group
author: Fariha Karim

https://www.thetimes.com/uk/law/article/.title: Squat mother in court over Extinction Rebellion blockade
https://www.thetimes.com/uk/law/article/.text:
A woman with nine children appeared in court yesterday with 50 others accused of being involved in an Extinction Rebellion blockade of printing presses.
Natalie Bracht, 45, appeared at Luton magistrates’ court via video link from Stevenage police station on one charge of obstruction of the highway. The court was told that she had been offered legal representation but turned it down.
She is among 51 people who have been charged with obstruction of the highway after the protest in Hertfordshire on Friday night. Extinction Rebellion targeted the Newsprinters print works, which produces newspapers including The Times, The Sun, The Daily Telegraph and the Daily Mail.
Ms Bracht initially failed to respond to questions about her name and personal details and did
image: Natalie Bracht lives in a squat near Heathrow and turned down legal representation when she appeared before magistrates yesterday
author: Fariha Karim

https://www.thetimes.com/uk/transport/ar.title: Trouble on the line as Extinction Rebellion protesters fight HS2
https://www.thetimes.com/uk/transport/ar.text: For a few weeks in 1996-97, it seemed that Daniel Hooper was the most famous man in England. Swampy, as he was known, spent seven days in tunnels excavated under the path of the enlarging A30 near Exeter. The A30 protest ultimately failed, but its like has been replicated several times since then and “Swampy” has become a catch-all for any environmental activist taking to the earth or the trees. It is a term that is being heard once again.\nHaving finally gained the backing of the prime minister just before the pandemic began, construction work started this month on Europe’s largest infrastructure project. The first phase of the HS2 rail line snaking through the Chilterns and Shakespeare country is due to deliver high-speed train
image: Protesters clash with security officials at the HS2 site in Denham, Buckinghamshire
